chapter.summary: Covers the management of children with confirmed mild-to-moderate cow's milk allergy in primary care.

subChapters.fullItemName: Scenario: Confirmed non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy

subChapters.htmlHeader: How should I manage confirmed mild-to-moderate non-IgE-mediated allergy?
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
If a diagnosis of mild-to-moderate non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy has been confirmed following a cow's milk elimination trial and subsequent home reintroduction:

  • Check whether referral to a specialist allergy clinic is needed, for example if a child develops clinical features of severe non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy.
  • Ensure referral to a paediatric dietitian has been arranged, who can provide:
    • Regular monitoring of growth and nutritional status (including faltering growth or excessive weight gain).
    • Advice on a cow's milk-free diet including hypoallergenic infant formulas and suitable substitute foods if complementary feeding (weaning).
    • Advice on performing a home reintroduction of cow's milk, and follow-up.
    • Advice on inappropriate dietary restriction; vitamin and calcium supplementation; and any feeding problems.
    • Advice if the child is already on a restricted diet for other reasons, which may be cultural or religious.
  • Advise strict adherence to a cow's milk-free diet for the mother/infant until the child is 9–12 months old and for at least 6 months. If symptoms do not improve over this time:
    • If cow's milk allergy is no longer suspected, the mother/infant may resume normal feeding and consider referral to a local paediatric service for further assessment if symptoms persist.
    • If cow's milk allergy is still suspected, arrange referral to a specialist allergy clinic and consider seeking specialist advice on the need to avoid soya protein and egg from the diet as well.
    • Note: The iMAP guidance notes that in exclusively breastfed infants, the likelihood of sufficient cow's milk protein passing into breast milk to trigger reactions is low, so complete cow's milk exclusion may not be needed.
  • Following a cow's milk-free diet, advise a planned home reintroduction of cow's milk into the mother's or infant's diet, to assess if tolerance has been acquired.
    • Note: if the child has signs of current atopic eczema or there is any history at any time of immediate-onset symptoms, do not advise a home reintroduction and instead arrange referral to an allergy specialist for allergy testing and ongoing management.
    • Tolerance to cow's milk protein should be assessed using a 'milk ladder' and monitoring for the return of symptoms.
      • A milk ladder reintroduces baked milk products first as heating reduces allergenicity. Once tolerance is established, greater exposure of less processed milk should be gradually encouraged, ending in the reintroduction of fresh cow's milk. The iMAP Milk Allergy Guideline Milk ladder and Milk ladder recipes leaflets may be helpful for parents/carers.
      • Advise parents/carers to have oral antihistamines available at home, in case there is a return of symptoms on reintroduction. See the section on Antihistamines in Prescribing information for more information.
      • If symptoms return on reintroduction of cow's milk, a cow's milk-free diet should be continued, and the child should be re-evaluated after a further 6 to 12 months.
  • Provide parents/carers with information on sources of advice and support.
  • Provide parents/carers with advice on food allergen avoidance, including prompt recognition of symptoms, the risks of accidental exposure, and tips when travelling. See the CKS topic on Food allergy for more information.

subChapters.htmlHeader: Basis for recommendation
subChapters.htmlStringContent:
The recommendations on managing confirmed non-IgE-mediated allergy are largely based on the National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) clinical guideline Food allergy in under 19s: assessment and diagnosis [NICE, 2018], the British Society for Allergy and Clinical Immunology (BSACI) publication BSACI guideline for the diagnosis and management of cow's milk allergy [Luyt et al, 2014], the European Academy of Allergy and Clinical Immunology (EAACI) publications Food Allergy and Anaphylaxis Guidelines [Muraro, 2014] and Diagnosis and management of non‐IgE gastrointestinal allergies in breastfed infants - an EAACI Position Paper [Meyer, 2019]; the European Society for Paediatric Gastroenterology, Hepatology and Nutrition (ESPGHAN) guidelines Diagnostic approach and management of cow’s-milk protein allergy in infants and children [Koletzko et al, 2012], and expert opinion in review articles on the management of cow's milk allergy [Ludman et al, 2013], on non-IgE-mediated cow's milk allergy [Venter et al, 2013; Venter, 2017], in the updated Milk allergy in primary care (MAP) guideline [Fox, 2019], and on the epidemiology of cow's milk allergy [Flom, 2019].

Arranging referral to a specialist allergy clinic
  • The recommendations on referral criteria for non-IgE-mediated allergy are based on a review of low-quality studies in the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], the ESPGHAN guidelines [Koletzko et al, 2012], and expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
Arranging referral to a paediatric dietitian
  • The recommendations to arrange a paediatric dietitian referral are based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], expert opinion in the updated iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter, 2017].
    • The recommendation on monitoring growth and nutritional status is based on the NICE guideline, the BSACI guideline, and expert opinion in a review article [Ludman et al, 2013].
      • The BSACI guideline advises that a dietitian assesses all children on a milk-free diet for calcium intake and gives advice on calcium-rich foods if needed, as well as regularly monitoring weight and growth. It notes that failure to involve a dietitian may lead to inappropriate feeding, prolonged unnecessary food exclusion, and nutritional deficiencies.
      • Malnutrition may occur in children on exclusion diets and children with newly diagnosed food allergies, as well as obesity [Ludman et al, 2013].
    • The recommendation on advising about suitable milk substitutes and substitute foods if complementary feeding (weaning), vitamin and calcium supplementation, and any feeding problems is based on expert opinion in a review article [Venter, 2017].
    • The recommendation on monitoring during an elimination trial and home reintroduction of cow's milk is based on the NICE clinical guideline, the BSACI guideline, the EAACI position paper on breastfed infants [Meyer, 2019], and the World Allergy Organization publication [Fiocchi et al, 2010].
      • The NICE guideline notes that an elimination diet can be initiated in primary care, however a dietitian should be involved to reduce the time to diagnosis, offer advice on nutritional issues, follow up, and advise on appropriate milk substitutes for formula-fed infants.
      • A diagnostic elimination diet should ideally be implemented with the support of a dietitian or nutritionist or suitably qualified healthcare professional, as this may prevent any negative nutritional impact [Meyer, 2019].
    • The recommendation on advising about restricted diets is extrapolated from the NICE guideline.
Maintaining a strict cow's milk-free diet
  • The recommendations on maintaining a strict cow's milk-free diet are based on the updated iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019] and are supported by expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter et al, 2013; Venter, 2017].
    • The recommendations on the duration of the cow's milk-free diet are based on the ESPGHAN guidelines [Koletzko et al, 2012], the updated iMAP guideline, and are supported by expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter et al, 2013].
    • The recommendations on management if symptoms do not improve during a cow's milk-free diet are based the updated iMAP guideline, which includes specialist allergy clinic referral if cow's milk allergy is still suspected, as the child may have multiple food allergies requiring more complex elimination regimens and assessment.
    • The iMAP guidance also notes that in exclusively breastfed infants, the likelihood of sufficient cow's milk protein passing into breast milk to trigger reactions is low, so complete cow's milk exclusion may not be needed.
Arranging a home reintroduction of cow's milk to assess for tolerance
  • The recommendations on how to perform a planned home reintroduction of cow's milk are based on the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014] and position paper [Meyer, 2019], the updated iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019], and expert opinion in a review article [Venter et al, 2013].
    • A home reintroduction should not be arranged if there is current atopic eczema. In these children, if allergy testing is positive, referral to a specialist allergy service should be arranged as a supervised oral food challenge may be needed. Similarly, if there is any history of immediate-onset symptoms at any time, allergy testing is needed with liaison or referral to a specialist allergy service as a supervised oral food challenge may be needed [Fox, 2019].
    • The recommendation to use a 'milk ladder' to gradually reintroduce cow's milk into the diet is based on the BSACI guideline, the EAACI position paper, and the updated iMAP guideline.
      • The introduction of baked milk to the diet may accelerate the development of tolerance, including to fresh milk. Once tolerance is established, greater exposure of less processed cow's milk should be according to the 'milk ladder'. Children become tolerant to baked milk before fresh milk as baking reduces protein allergenicity, so reintroduction with baked milk should be attempted before fresh milk [Luyt et al, 2014].
      • The BSACI guideline notes, however, that there is little evidence on the effect of processing on the allergenicity of specific foods, and therefore use of the milk ladder may result in a bigger than anticipated step-up in exposure.
      • Expert opinion in a review article notes that gradual reintroduction of baked milk products via the milk ladder accelerates the development of tolerance to cow's milk compared with a complete milk exclusion approach [Venter et al, 2013].
    • The recommendation for parents/carers to have oral antihistamines at home in case there is a recurrence of symptoms is based on the BSACI guideline.
    • If symptoms return following a home reintroduction, the recommendation to reassess tolerance at 6–12 monthly intervals from 12 months of age is based on the BSACI guideline. This approach is supported by the ESPGHAN and EAACI guidelines, which note that reassessment for tolerance at regular intervals potentially avoids inappropriate or unnecessarily lengthy dietary eliminations that may impair quality of life and the child's nutrition and growth, as well as incurring additional healthcare costs.
Advising on sources of information and support
  • The recommendation to offer information and support is based on the NICE clinical guideline [NICE, 2018], the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guidelines [Muraro, 2014], the World Allergy Organization publication [Fiocchi et al, 2010], the updated iMAP guideline [Fox, 2019], and expert opinion in review articles [Ludman et al, 2013; Venter et al, 2013; Martorell-Aragones, 2015; Venter, 2017].
  • The recommendation to provide education on allergen avoidance to reduce the risk of accidental milk exposure is based on the BSACI guideline [Luyt et al, 2014], the EAACI guideline [Muraro, 2014], and is supported by expert opinion in a review article [Venter et al, 2013].
